oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sheet of draft poems
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Page 1: 3 lines beginning: "Seemed, but gently whispering:"; 1 line: "The whole head is sick and the whole heart faint."; 14 lines beginning: "Woe for the young [inserted: "who"] say that life is long" [Reversed , at foot]: "These are early poems (say 1847) by Christina G. Rossetti. The handwriting at back is my mother's."; Page 2: 4 four-line stanzas headed: "A true Story. (continued)", beginning: "In this great city now the haunt" and footed: "(To be continued)";

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mr. Brown [Ford Madox Brown?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Friday morning, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Lucy kindly writing to help us in a search for seaside lodgings..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mr. Gurney [Alfred, 1845-1898?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Friday, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "It is a pleasure to hear from you again, and to read and to return the agreeable 'Academy' critique."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Sir" [editor? of University Magazine]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nov. 15, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "My brother William Rossetti tells me that you will accept something of mine for your 'University Magazine' ... "; Sewed into blank sheet marked: 139 Christina Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Miss Knox [Isa Craig?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Friday evening, 166 Albany St. N.W.; Begins: "Will you allow me the privilege of introducing to you a lady, Mrs Macquoid?..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mr. Scott [William Bell?].
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: New Year's night, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "I hope I am first to show you a few pleasant words from the Guardian "

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Madam"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 13 Nov (Thursday), 45 Upper Albany St. N.W.; Begins: "Mme Bodichon, asking me to contribute a little piece to the volume to be sold at the Lancashire Distress Exhibition..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Sir"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1885 Aug 5, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Text: "Allow me to thank you for the pleasure you have given me by sending me a review I had neither seen nor heard of."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to William Michael Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1889 Mar 13 , 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Receipt for the quarter's rent for 5 Endsleigh Gardens. Signed "Christina G. Rossetti for Charlotte L. Polidori". On verso: penciled sums.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Sir"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Saturday, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Even with your valuable and kind help -- for which I gratefully thank you -- I have been unable to collect sufficient material for a memoir of Mrs Radcliffe..." [From folder 23D.4, formerly marked 3]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "My dear William" [Michael Rossetti]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Begins: "I hope your new home pleases you..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Lady Louisa Feilding [Fielding?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1890] Jan 8, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Subject: the death of Charlotte Polidori; tell Lady Bath (if you think the news should reach her). Mourning paper.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mrs. Gilchrist [Anne Gilchrist, n_e Burrows?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday evening, 166 Albany St., London, N.W.; Begins: "Thank you for such a delightfully kind letter"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mrs. Gilchrist [Anne Gilchrist, n_e Burrows?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Monday, 166 Albany St., London, N.W.; Begins: "I hope the temporary loss of the paper..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mrs. Gilchrist [Anne Gilchrist, n_e Burrows?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Monday Morning, 166 Albany St., London, N.W.; Begins: "I congratulate you most warmly on the improvement in health..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mrs. Gilchrist [Anne Gilchrist, n_e Burrows?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Wednesday, 8th, 45 Upper Albany St., London, N.W.; Begins: "I will not lose a post in letting you know about William's possibilities"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mrs. Gilchrist [Anne Gilchrist, n_e Burrows?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Saturday, 21st, 45 Upper Albany St., London, N.W.; Begins: "I have indeed often thought of my prospective visit to Brookbank..." On mourning paper (thin margin).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mrs. Gilchrist [Anne Gilchrist, n_e Burrows?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 7th April, 56 Euston Square, N.W.; Begins: "I might not know how to excuse my not having yet returned..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mrs. Gilchrist [Anne Gilchrist, n_e Burrows?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday evening, 56 Euston Square, N.W.; Begins: "Please accept my little note of sympathy in your suffering"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mrs. Gilchrist [Anne Gilchrist, n_e Burrows?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Friday afternoon, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Thank you for remembering me who have dropped out of the circle! "

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mrs. Gilchrist [Anne Gilchrist, n_e Burrows?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Monday, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "I hear from my brother that you are suffering"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mrs. Gilchrist [Anne Gilchrist, n_e Burrows?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday, Care of Miss Boyd, Penkill Castle, Girvan, N.B.; Begins: "Thank you for your very kind disappointment showing a regard for me"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mrs. Gilchrist [Anne Gilchrist, n_e Burrows?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1868 June 14, 31 Trafalgar Square, Scarborough.; Begins: "Would you believe that it was a real relief to me to find"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to William Bryant
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tuesday, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Without reminding you of anything I have said already, let me say that I do not quite like your scheme as I cannot but doubt whether your acquaintance can be aware of the value of the books he offers you"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to William Bryant
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1886 July 10] Saturday, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Well-- ! Only pray do your utmost..." Heavy mourning. Envelope postmarked JY 10 86.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Envelope addressed to William Bryant
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [Postmark: London JY 10 86]; Envelope addressed to William Bryant Esq / 7 Spa Cottages / Green Terrace / Clerkenwell EC

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tuesday morning, on Torrington Square letterhead; Text: "'We took sweet counsel together, and walked in the House of God as friends.' Hearty congratulations to Mr. Gurney touching the Crypt recess. CGR."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tuesday evening, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Even before I looked for one, comes an answer from Mr. Gutch"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to unknown recipient regarding Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [End of a letter. Not to Shields, but offering a covert apology to Shields by way of the recipient.] Begins: "the pleasure of seeing you. It was Aunt Eliza who with us visited Mr Shields studio..." Ends: "With all loves, especially our Mother's, your affectionate Christina G. Rossetti. We won't despair of staying with you at a more propitious time."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Postcard to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1884 Jy 4 [postmark], no place.; Begins: "We hope all three..." [1 postcard]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Postcard to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1885 Mar 27, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Please accept a card of t hanks" [1 postcard]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Postcard to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1885 Apr 30 [postmark] Thursday, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "I am forwarding data to Miss H" [1 postcard]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Friday evening, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Thank you again and again. No one perhaps can estimate what poor Gabriel has been going thro'..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1881 Dec 16, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Your letter came like balm"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1882] Apr 8, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Dear Friend. You have prayed for us.." Broad mourning.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1882], Apr 13, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Thank you for thinking of me amid such associations ..." Medium mourning.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1882 Apr 30, 5 Endsleigh Gardens, London, N.W.; Printed mourning card from Wm. M. Rossetti and Lucy M. Rossetti. "Dante Gabriel Rossetti. Our thanks for sympathy." Not addressed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1883 July 25, Church Hill, Birchington-on-Sea; Begins ( p. 1): "My Mother joins me now in thanking you for the warm reception you accord to her wish, and bids me explain the 100L is not..." p.5: "of genius and devotion not ratable by a money standard..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1883?] Aug 1, Church Hill, Birchington-on-Sea; Begins (p.1): "How I hope that Birchington --if Birchington prove to be your -- " p.5: "Mr Harris Jessamine Cottage.. " [notes describing possible lodgings for Shields.]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1883 Aug 20, Church Hill, Birchington-on-Sea; Begins : "I fear the sight of my handwriting may perturb"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1883 Aug 23, Church Hill, Birchington-on-Sea; Begins: "I lost no time in going round to the Post Office"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1884 Feb 20, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Benignly read my enclosure"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1884?] Oct 4, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "The paragraph in a recent Athenaeum which announces your forthcoming window upbuilds our hope"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tuesday, [Torrington paper]; Begins: "My Mother with warm remembrances desires me to send you"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday morning, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "My Mother wishes that as you revive her hope"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Friday, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "I am laying myself out to be disagreeable! Perhaps"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1884?] Sep 1, 6 [sic] Station Road, Birchington-on-Sea; Begins: "At length , last Tuesday, we came hither"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1884?] Friday 3rd, 5 Station Road, Birchington-on-Sea; Begins: "I hope your next letter will tell us that your wife is better"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1884?] Oct 1, 5 Station Road, Birchington-on-Sea; Begins: "Here we are still a t Birchington, and you know what we are thinking"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1884?] Oct 24, 5 Station Road, Birchington-on-Sea; Begins: "At last I enjoy the pleasure of telling you that we have seen the beaul worth-waiting-for window"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Saturday, 5 Station Road, Birchington-on-Sea; Begins: "I am very glad you sent me notes of your beaul light ..." Hasty sketch on p. 4, probably of church window. By Shields?

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1885 or1886] Apr 22, 30 Torrington Square, London, W.C.; Begins: "We are so sorry, my Mother and I, to know that you are ill and" Annotated in red ink by Shields.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Friday morning, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins: "Our conversation of last evening"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Monday morning, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins (p.1): "Thank you for excusing and remedying my momentary lapse..." p. 5: "Old Testament utterances, "

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Friday afternoon, [Torrington paper]; Begins: "I return Dr. Acland's letter"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: May 9, [Torrington paper]; Begins: "Thank you for such full details concerning the 2 books of reference!..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Wednesday, [Torrington paper]; Begins: "Matters brighten! I enclose Mr Macdonald's letter"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1894] Sep 5, 30 Torrington Square, W.C.; Begins (p.1): "Let us say Good bye for this life ... "; pp 2,4-5 blank; continues ( p. 6): "to Others and is herself what God knows her to be..."; pp 7-8 blank. Annotated by Shields in pencil (p.3): "Christina Rossetti went home on Dec 29th--this was written after I had been told I could not see her. Frederic Shields."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from C. Tomlinson to Christina Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: C. Tomlinson; 1878 Feb 2, [3, Ridgmount, Highgate, N. paper]; Begins: "I am greatly obliged to you for sending me these volumes on Dante..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from William Morris to Christina Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William Morris; 1882 Sep 4., [Kelmscott House, Upper Mall, Hammersmith paper]; Begins: "Dear Miss Rossetti. Thank you for your kind remembrances; I am sorry I was obliged to give a nay say to Mrs Bolton..." Annotated [by Christina Rossetti?]: "Author of 'The Earthly Paradise'"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Raleigh's Cell in the Tower.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Raleigh's cell in the Tower. Fair copy. Sonnet. Published, according to W. M. Rossetti (in DGM's Poetical Works, 1887), in Caine's Sonnets of Three Centuries (1882). Handwriting differs somewhat from Rossetti's letters to Haydon and Blackmore.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Day-Dream
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Day-Dream. Fair copy: differs from published text. Sonnet. Published in Ballads and Sonnets (1881) in a slightly different version: apparently describes a picture by Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Love-Moon
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Love-Moon. Fragment of draft. Before 1869. Sonnet 37 from The House of Life. Published in his Poems (1870). Mounted on card. Includes first half of all lines; with corrections.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cheque to the order of H. [Henry] T. [Treffrey] Dunn for 50 pounds
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cheque to the order of H. [Henry] T. [Treffrey] Dunn for 50 pounds (No Ap50222 on the Union Bank of London), 4 Jan 1878. Mounted on card.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Alfred St. Johnston
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter to Alfred St. Johnston, (ca 1858-1891), enclosing "two specimens of my brother's writing" (3a. and 3b. above). 5 Endsleigh Gardens, 5 June 1882. On mourning paper.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Jonathan Tong
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 15 Nov 1865, Cheyne Walk; Discussing the possible subjects of a small picture commissioned by Tong, price at least 300 guineas. "I never do compositions on a small scale in oil"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Smetham [James Smetham]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 4 Sept 1871, The Manor House, Kelmscott, Lechlade; "Morris and I took the house together, and I am expecting him to join me..."; description of house and region, comic description of tapestry. About to return to half-finished "big daub."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Postcard to F. G. Stephens [Frederic George Stephens]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1 Mar 1880] Cheyne Walk; Asking for information on the artist W. Blakey. Addressed to 10 Terrace, Hammersmith; postmarked Mr 2 80. With penciled note on Blakey (by the recipient?: Frederic George Stephens, 1828-1907, art-critic.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Haydon [Haydon, Samuel J. B.]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 6 Apr 1875, Cheyne Walk; Your project of publishing etchings as a series impossible because of my temperament: "a vol: or nothing." "A labour of love...while pictures are a labour of lucre" Interested in the Fuseli facsimile. 3 pages guarded

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to G. F. Watts
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tuesday 10 August, 16 Cheyne Walk; Begins:" I have a favour to ask of you; in the way of an exchange. I much wish to possess (not for myself) the head you sketched of me in oil."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Envelope addressed to Mr. Allingham Esq.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Envelope addressed to Mr. Allingham Esq / Lane Ballyshannon / Ireland

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to o [Benjamin Horatio Paul (Paulos Patkon)]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tuesday Evening; Begins "Do try & come & meet Scott at my crib on Friday Evening."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to My dear Aunt [Charlotte Polidori]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday, [16 Cheyne Walk, Chelsea letterhead]; Begins: "I thought I gathered from your letter that Lord & Lady "]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Dear Sir [Hayward Esq]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 3 Nov 1862; 16 Cheyne Walk, Chelsea; Begins: "I have done the little circular panels for your cabinet, & have written to that effect to Mr Seddon."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to My Dear Sir
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 11 Jan 1864, [16 Cheyne Walk, Chelsea letterhead]; Begins: " My friend Mr Knewstub, bearer of this will show you some drawings which have lately been shown to Mr Mark Lemon."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to H. V. Tebbs [H. V. (Henry Virtue) Tebbs ]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1864 June 18, [16 Cheyne Walk, Chelsea letterhead]; Begins: "Seddon will come to dinner next Tuesday at 7."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter fragment to Scott
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1867 Apr 3, [16 Cheyne Walk, Chelsea letterhead]; Fragment only; Text on verso in Rossetti's hand begins, "[] the place which is near one corner of"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Dear Sir [Perry]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1868 May 14, [16 Cheyne Walk, Chelsea letterhead]; Begins: "I send you the enclosed 2 copies of the agreement which I am quite ready to sign at once" Pencil notation on the last page: "RossettiDante Gabriel Rossetti"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Envelope addressed to A. W. Deacon
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [Postmark: London MY 18 72]; Envelope addressed to A. W. Deacon Esq / London Students' Gazette / 4 Crane Court / Fleet Street EC

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Dearest Teak [Frances Polidori]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Wednesday; Begins: "I was delayed upon coming today."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Clarence E. Fry
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1875 Oct 7, 16 Cheyne Walk; "Begins: Since I saw you I have been detained in town, and within the last 6 weeks have begun and completed a new picture." Discussion of Venus Astarte. Incomplete.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mr Turner [W. A. Turner?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Begins: "On further thinking"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Dear Mr Hall_ [Charles Edward Hall_]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1878 Mar 14, 16 Cheyne Walk; Begins: "Mr W. B. Scott, one of the few truly poetic-minded painters among us"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Lord Mount-Temple [Baron Mount-Temple, William Francis Cowper-Temple]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1881 Jan, 16 Cheyne Walk; Begins: "My oldest & dearest friend, Ford Madox Brown, is very desirous if possible to fill with his work one of the remaining picture spaces in the House of Lords."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Visiting Card
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Visiting Card, "Mr D. G. Rossetti. 16 Cheyne Walk, Chelsea" with pencil message. Begins:" Saturday. Will you come down to dinner today"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Algernon Charles Swinburne
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1871 Nov 6, Cheyne Walk; Pseudonymity of B.B. [i.e. on Robert Buchanan's pseudonymous attack "The fleshly School of Poetry" and Rossetti's envisaged retort: wants Swinburne's comments. Swinburne makes himself vulnerable by his wild japes, which he should give up. Awaiting publication of Prelude to Tristan: Swinburne should not get into such a publication mess again. Description of his poem Rose Mary. Brown's illustrations to R. Hffer. [Envelope (dated 7th) may not go with this letter, but likely does.]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Algernon Charles Swinburne
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [no date] Reply to Swinburne's reply to item 1. Shall change retort as Swinburne wishes. Swinburne should be careful not to circulate things he does not want to be made public: "Every line you have ever written will one day be religiously raked up by... exploiteurs..." even though his friends should properly destroy them. Literary gossip.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Algernon Charles Swinburne
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1867?] Tuesday, Cheyne Walk; Invitation to dinner; Swinburne's Blake; facsimile of Blake's Marriage of Heaven and Hell good news.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Wednesday. "The profile is left out in readiness..." With doodle.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Monday. [Herne Bay?]; "I don't know whether you are in or out of town"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Monday; "Will Thursday suit you to dine"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday; "I will hope to see you to paint"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sunday; "I may probably be sending for the mantle"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tuesday; "I'm afraid things seem to militate against your coming"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday; "After all I find that Wed..."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Monday; "Everything miscarries, and this is my third evening" With sum.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Wednesday; "It is unpleasant to hear of your having suffered"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Monday; "Did you get my note (posted Saturday"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1879 July 16; "I was most glad to hear that Mrs. Fields"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Postcard to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1878 Sept 4] Cheyne Walk; "You might tell friend B. "

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Monday; "Tomorrow (Tuesday) will suit me, and I advise"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Saturday; "I cannot say that the letter of Richard's Kinsman"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday night; "I much wanted to talk to you"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday; "I will hope to see you tomorrow (Friday) tho'"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sunday; "I fear by your not coming"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday, [Liverpool?]; "Samuelson has decided against the varnishing"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Monday; "I remember it was not quite settled"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Friday; "I shd be very glad if Monday suited you"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday; "I will not look for you tomorrow"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sunday [?]; "I will hope to see you on Tuesday, trusting that Mrs Shields"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tuesday; "I was sorry to miss you and to hear of Miss"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday; "I quite forgot to ask you yesterday"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday; "In spite of what I wrote" With doodle.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1864 June 14, Cheyne Walk; Sent with gift of his Early Italian Poets. His drawings; Shield's designs. Mills (Ernestine Mills. The Life and Letters of Frederick Shields, 1912.) publishes (p. 83) as first Rossetti-Shields letter.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1868 Feb 21. Cheyne Walk; Helping Warwick Brookes; selling the Vineyard and St George cartoons to W. Johnson. Exhibiting the Tristram drawing at Leeds: I do not wish minor exhibitions; can you influence Tong, Mendel, etc., to drop it? Your Drummer-boy, Rehab. Chapman, Brown. Would welcome you to London. Mostly published Mills (Ernestine Mills. The Life and Letters of Frederick Shields, 1912) pages 117-119.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1869 Dec 24; Sponsoring Brown; Colvin; Graham's extraordinary conduct concerning the commission; my health and sight; drink. Have resumed painting and drawing; Dante's Dream, Found, Medusa; plans; studio-building. Poetry volume forthcoming; Morris' Paradise; Tennyson. Craven; Brown's watercolour of Don Juan; Ned Jones. Partly published Mills (Ernestine Mills. The Life and Letters of Frederick Shields, 1912) pages 137-139.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1870 Aug 28, Cheyne Walk; Gratitude for friendship; trouble with Mitchell; your trouble with Graham. In country's financial situation "art goes first to the wall." My poem Jenny; book well received. Blackwood's. "My mind is now quite occupied with my painting": Dante's Dream. "A big picture is glorious work." Health, sight. Brown; Burne-Jones; Burton; Dunn. Partly published Mills (Ernestine Mills. The Life and Letters of Frederick Shields, 1912) pages 142-144.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1871 Jan 12, Cheyne Walk; Water-Colour Gallery; I never leave home in daylight; good and bad paper for chalk-drawings. Mitchell trouble. Magdalene may be ready for next year's show; finishing Beatrice, Sibylla Palmifera, Mariana, Pandora. Dante. My temperament. McConnel's painting not sold. I've been trying unsuccessfully to find you buyers. Scott and Manchester. Artist neighbors. Partly published Mills (Ernestine Mills. The Life and Letters of Frederick Shields, 1912) pages 145-147.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Frederic James Shields
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1877 Oct 21, Herne Bay; Perhaps Turner would buy the little picture at a lower price. "I have...made solid progress in the merit of my work...within the last 5 years..." and brightness has characterised my best works (list) except for Astarte: they are not injured by my drug habit. Brown. Chalk heads of mother and sister. Rae my first buyer. Mostly published by Mills (Ernestine Mills. The Life and Letters of Frederick Shields, 1912) pages 217-219.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Ernest Gambart
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1864 April 2; Subject: Our agreement for so many drawings during a stated time must be modified: the first 2 large female figures from nature were too troublesome for the price [details of market prices and proposed solutions], though they are a relief from those done without using nature. MUTILATED: Cheyne Walk heading and signature cut out, with some loss of text. Docketed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Ernest Gambart
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1864 April 4 , on Cheyne Walk letterhead; Subject: Not at all; I have always been satisfied with your behavior to me; my original proposal was too hasty and I apologise. Of course you need not feel bound to take either of the modified proposals . The more profit you can get the better my position is established, and I prefer quick turnover to holding them back for a high price, or troubling "myself to offer them to amateur friends." Three more drawings should be done next week. Docketed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Ernest Gambart
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1865 Dec 20, on Cheyne Walk letterhead; I regret having accepted the story which you assure me is untrue. Surely neither Ruskin nor any artists will disbelieve you. "As to Mr Mendel -- if his retaining the picture or not depends on anything but his own liking for it, he must be but a weak vessel." I myself will take any price I can get . I will investigate the source of the tale. MUTILATED: signature cut out with loss of text; TEARING at corners of cut. NOTE: DGR had sold his The Blue Bower to Gambart for 200 guineas, and boasted in November that it had been re-sold (to Sam Mendel of Manchester, a Manchester textile merchant) for 1500 guineas. Gambart complained that this was private information, that the re-sale figure was exaggerated, that the gossip had alienated Ruskin and was bad for business. (See Maas pp 185-188, Surtees 178.) Docketed. Tearing.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Ernest Gambart
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1867 Jan [11]; Subject: The small picture is done; will you send for it? Your bill is coming due; may I renew it [proposes terms], or paint you a picture for it? MUTILATED: Cheyne Walk heading [?] and signature cut out; HANDLE WITH CARE. Docketed 1864 Rossetti Jany 11th.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Ernest Gambart
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1867 Jan 12; Subject: A (secret) cut-rate price for the little picture because you had purchased an unprofitable one. If it is unsuccessful, I'll substitute an ordinary watercolour since I've already been offered a good price. I repeat, I am not responsible for the story and do not wish to hear about it again. MUTILATED: Cheyne Walk heading [?] and signature cut out with loss of text. Docketed. Handle with care.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. Blackmore (William Blackmore)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1863 Nov 6, London; The artist acknowledges a note enclosing a check in payment for a recently completed picture which is for a sum greater than the amount agreed upon. "That you are pleased with it is very grying to me... I will beg you to accept the frame with the picture (which I had made from a design of my own, thinking you would prefer such to a casual one)." Because of the overpayment to which he feels he hasn't the slightest claim, he proposes to send the sketch which first induced his correspondent to commission the painting (Fazio's Mistress [Surtees 164]).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. Blackmore (William Blackmore)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1863 Nov 19, London; Concerning his arrangements for delivering the picture to Mr. Blackmore and referring to a few changes which he thinks have improved it. A long postscript explains the inscription on the frame, with the lettering not quite dry. It was taken from a poem of Fazio degli Uberti's included in the artist's "Early Italian Poets," and he gives a translation of it. Suggestions for the best lighting for this painting.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mrs. Blackmore
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1863 Nov 24; London; To Mrs. Blackmore inquiring about the safe arrival of the picture.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. Blackmore (William Blackmore)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1865 Dec 1; London; Offering a picture on which he has just begun to work. "...the figure rather under life-scale, & the canvas a little smaller than the large Venus you saw here and its price will be 500 guineas." [Perhaps Monna Vanna (Surtees 191)]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. Blackmore (William Blackmore)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1867 Feb 2; London; Reflecting the artist's well-known enthusiasm for strange and grotesque animals. He thanks his correspondent for arranging to send him a hollow tree. "Nine feet would be just about the thing...I have just looked at my owls, who are in the grandest feather." He goes on to comment on Melville's Omoo, comparing it with Defoe and Poe's "Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sentiment/Poem
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sentiment: "There shall no evil befal thee E. E. Siddal."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "My very dear friend" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti?)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Subject: Journey home good. A. and E. interested in my experiences and send love to you and your husband. Your tender friendship; my ill health. Quote Psalms, Pusey. "...'hanselled' as we say in the North..." Domestic news; tell F. Mary found a Gnu in her book. A. poorly. Remains of paper hinges. Greenwell was a poet and essayist; sister of the antiquarian Canon William Greenwell of Durham. (Recipient may not be Lucy, since the Dictionary of National Biography indicates that after 1866 Dora left Durham for London and elsewhere.) Not annotated by William Michael Rossetti; but found in "Rossetti family 2" folder with other letters to Lucy. Date: "your husband"; therefore 1874 or later.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dearest Mrs Rossetti" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti?)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Wednesday, 126 Portsdown Road, Maida Vale; Subject: We are so grieved to have missed seeing you today..." Do come in, even when we're in disarray. Do thank the givers of the book which I have so longed for since seeing it in Philip's library. Longing to see the baby (female) again. Blue intricate monogram IZA.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dearest Lucy" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1875-1886?], [London:] Acacia Road: Eaton House; Subject: Packing almost done; your invitation to stay for a few days at Euston Square before leaving is very convenient. Dating: watermark 1875; Rossetti's left Euston Square ca. 1886.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "My Dear Lucy" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Subject: Sorry to have missed you because of doctor. Come again tomorrow. Signed "Mathilde" .

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Mrs Rossetti" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1877 Aug 6, [London:] Park Lane: 20 North Row; Subject: Apology for missing your evenings: brother's return & my foot. Payne was a translator of The Decameron.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "My dear Mrs Rossetti" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1879 May 5, [London: Park Lane:] 20 North Row; Subject: Sorry missed calling on you last Friday; next Friday?

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Mrs. Rossetti" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1883 [July 9?], Howard House, Stoke Newington Green, London. Subject: Sending you the large paper copy (your father's was from the publisher). Your illness. I may be able to supply 3 or 4 extra copies at the small-paper subscription price of 7/-. Annotated (by William Michael Rossetti):"... relates to his memoirs of Oliver Madox Brown"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "My dear Mrs Rossetti" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1881 or later], letterhead: 20, Earl's Terrace, Kensington. W.; Answering your note since Mary has bad cold; we had better visit you next week, but I'll probably drop in this Thursday. Best to Mr Rossetti. Annotated (by William Michael Rossetti): "___ 'Mary' is the present Mrs Darmestater." Cream-pink paper with warm silver-grey embossed address. Violet Paget was the birth name of the writer whose pen name was Vernon Lee.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dearest Mrs Rossetti" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1888 or earlier], letterhead: 20, Earl's Terrace, Kensington. W.; "It is not that I should be too tired after the dressmaker, but all the afternoon trains are so bad, so I will" arrive 1:28. Best from Mother to the "sweet patient." "your loving Mary R." Annotated (by William Michael Rossetti): "Mary Robinson, now Mme Darmesteter..." Blue-grey card with thin black embossed address.
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Robinson, A. Mary F. (Agnes Mary Frances), 1857-1944 (aut)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Bonne et chere Mme" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1884 May 14, Paris 55 rue St Louis en l'Isle; [In French.] Your letter reminded me of your excellent father's friendship. I'm about to visit England, invalid as I am, inspired by my sympathy for your country and your School of Art, and meet at last you and your husband, whom I consider friends. I shan't take advantage of the hospitality you offered, because of illness, and because I'll be accompanied by my son-in-law. But I would like to dine with you, and meet certain people. Plan to go to London, Manchester, Coniston, Farnley Hall, London.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "My dear Mrs. [?] Rossetti" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 188[4?] Oct 22, The Pines, Putney Hill; Subject: I will attend to the reconveyance. "I never sent you in my account for making the conveyance from" [end of p. 1] "and this has much disturbed me...thrown me off my work" Incomplete? The 2 pages are the two sides of a half-sheet. Although both salutation and signature are present, the text does not seem to join: the second page may be the bottom half of a full sheet. Broad mourning.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Mrs. Rossetti" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1886 Oct 18, Whitehall, Clondalkin [co. Dublin]; [Sentimental and respectful.] The cup and saucer I gave you is Belleck ware (deserves to be better known). Meant to keep you supplied with flowers this summer as in previous summers, but my helpful sister was away. Glad Mr Rossetti liked "Death and the Man," my next book (ready for May) should be an improvement. So indebted to you and Mr Rossetti. Wis hed to send Miss Rossetti flowers, but feared it would be an intrusion. "Katie Tynan." Annotated (by William Michael Rossetti): "Katherine Tynan (now Mrs Hinkson) Poetess"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Mrs. Rossetti" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1892 Mar 30, Siena House, Lodge Place N.W.; Subject: Can you lend some of your father's drawings for Friday evening as Mr Holiday desires may "issue in something profitable." Hear you have been ill again. (Henry Holiday, 1839-1927, PRB painter & stained-glass maker.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Mrs. Rossetti" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Friday, The Green, Southwick, Sussex; Subject: Accepting your invitation for the 6th.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dearest Lucy" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1877 Nov 2, Hotel de Flandres, Bruges; Subject: Same hotel we were at with you and William two years ago; Bruges full of smells. Overslept so could not wish you goodbye. Ghent next. Love from us to baby. Olive, William, and you. Cathy pretty well. [Paper embossed "London Superfine"]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dearest Lucy" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1881 Aug 5, 37 Fitzroy Square W.; Subject: We have rented a pretty cottage in Manchester for 28 pounds, so half our London furniture must be stored by you and by Shields; your adventure with the superior landlady worrying about the babies. Mathilde ill; have not told her about Trelawney. Cathy. Christina sent Emma her book, but she and Mrs Rossetti have vanished. My infected foot; old Blake a bother. Sorry could not join you and William in country. Now rid of this house and on lookout for London cottage.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dearest Lucy" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1881 Nov, 30 Calais Cottage, Crumpsall, Manchester; Subject: Please cash this cheque for me. Problems with surveying the house: Watts, Robinson, Russell, the Scharifs [?]; you can be a witness of how it was when we first went in to it. Christmas gift for Olive; Emma working doll's clothes; kisses for the chicks.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dearest Lucy" (Lucy Madox Brown Rossetti)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1886 Jun 18. Vic'a Park, Manchester (broad mourning); Subject: Miss Pottock's answer. I've been annotating Mademoiselle's translation of "The Black Swan," but she's a poor translator. Harold at Arundel has written about Lafage to his brother. ANNOTATED IN PENCIL: "Brown -- 1st sentence refers to arrangements consequent on death of a cousin -- Mademoiselle was our nursery-governess Madlle Combrisson who had undertaken to translate Oliver Brown's book. Lafage married her -- Harold is H. Rathbone." (This is a pre-Paden note.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Richard Bentley
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1857 May 8; 45 Upper Albany St. N. W.; Subject: calling publishers attention to oriental sketches of the late Thomas Seddon at the Society of Arts.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mr. Stark [?].
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [ca. 1886?] Feb. 7, 5 Endsleigh Gardens, N.W.; Subject: instructions on "packet of Shelley-work", including permission to show it to Mr. Chatto.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Postcard to W.B. Slater
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1888 May 19, 73 Marine Parade, Worthing; Subject: mentions gout and Browning meeting, in London on his return.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to A. Carter, with envelope
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1892 March 6, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Subject: regarding photographic portrait of Dante Rossetti, probably available from The Stereoscopic Co., Regent St. London. Also a stamped envelope to Carter, in W. M. Rossettis hand dated April 5, 1892.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. L. Longstaff [W. Luther (William Luther) Longstaff]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1892 April 21, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Subject: comments on a volume of Longstaffs poems received.
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: W. L. Longstaff [W. Luther (William Luther) Longstaff] (rcp)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Rev. Dr. Thompson
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1896 July 9, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Subject: regretting that he cannot attend Massinger meeting.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Sir"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1897 May 22, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Subject: providing dates of school, marriage, and retirement.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Rev. R. Wilkins Rees, with envelope
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1900 Mar 31, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Subject: sending a copy of his fathers Cracovia (1847), bearing Christinas signature. Mentioning sister Marias Shadow of Dante and life. Stamped envelope intact.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Dear Sir
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1900 June 3, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Subject: acknowledging present and letter of 14 May, return from Italy 31 May, and mentioning lack of signed letter by Ruskin or Swinburne for gift, also a letter received from recipients sister before leaving England.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Diagnostic intake slip from the practice of Professor G. Keith-Harvey, completed in W. M. Rossetti's hand
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1906 June 7; Diagnostic intake slip from the practice of Professor G. Keith-Harvey, 117, Holborn, London, E. C., completed in W. M. Rossetti's hand. Gives details of loss of hearing and answers other health questions.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Dear Sirs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1913 Nov 30, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Subject: denying he ever wrote anything under the title "Leaves of Grass," except to edit some of Whitman "of course printing his name."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Sir
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: April 1, 45 Upper Albany St. N. W.; Begins: "Mr Holman Hunt having informed me that you have been so kind as to express a wish to be furnished with some of the circulars for"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Gerald Foster
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1879 Oct 5; Begins: "My friend Mr Holman Hunt wrote to me the day before yesterday saying that you wish some details about our late valued friend John Tupper"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to A. Carter
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1892 April 5, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Begins: "The last letter wh. I received from you shows that you wd like to possess an auto-graph of my brother's. I enclose one: it is not of a poetical kind"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Dear Sir
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1902 Feb 16, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Begins: "I have received your letter about Dumas. It is perfectly true that my Brother took the greatest delight in reading Dumas, & I think it may be said that he seriously considered him a great writer."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mr. Howe
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1906 Jan 17, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Begins: "I also have been reading Hunt's book: find it truly very interesting"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Postcard to "Profr. Chew", Bryn Mawr College, Bryn Mawr PA.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1918 Feb 10, 3. St. Edmund's Terrace, London, N.W. 8; Begins: When I spontaneously undertook to write that criticism I informed Sw[inburne], who had cordially approved"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Martin Colles
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1898 Aug 7, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Subject: discussing enclosed photos & drawings to accompany "Some scraps...by Dante Gabriel Rossetti", Pall Mall Magazine, Dec., 1898.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Martin Colles
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1906 Mar 2, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Subject: with MS 23W.2:3, letters to the agent on the subject of his editorial work on the letters of Dante Gabriel and Christina, discussing editing, revision, and additions, looking forward to later publication.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Martin Colles
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1906 Nov 19, 3 St. Edmund's Terrace, Regents Park N. W.; Subject: with MS 23W.2:2, letters to the agent on the subject of his editorial work on the letters of Dante Gabriel and Christina, discussing editing, revision, and additions, looking forward to later publication.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mr. Little
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [18]86 August 5, 5 Endsleigh Gardens, N. W.; Subject: Asking Little, for the Shelley Society, to see if part in "Hellas or Cenci" could be given to Mrs. Petrici (Miss Edmeston). Black mourning border. Note "Answered 5 Aug. 86"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mr. Little
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [18]86 August 6, 5 Endsleigh Gardens, N. W.; Subject: Mentioning Mrs. Petrici, Furnivall, expenses of Shelley Society, and appointments. Black mourning border. Note: "Answered 8 & 10 Aug."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mr. Little
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [18]86 August 27, 5 Endsleigh Gardens, N. W.; Subject: Enclosing unsigned letter from unknown correspondent concerning money, referring to Mr. Clausen and Professor Pierce. Black mourning border.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from George P. Boyce to William Michael Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1857 Aug 10], Strand, [London]; Subject: correspondence regarding pencil sketches and a pencil portrait. [Mutilated, with top left portion of text missing]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Ed. of P. M. G. [Editor of the Pall Mall Gazette] to William Michael Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1865 Mar 9; Begins: "The History of Caricature will be sent to you early tomorrow morning"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Isa Craig to William Michael Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1865] Dec 13, 1 Adam St. Adelphi [London]; Begins: "To-morrow I will read & decide upon your friend's M.S. "

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from T. G. Hake [Thomas Gordon Hake] to Mr. Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1872 Aug 3; Begins: "No particular news-- Your brother has had a quiet night as he admits; and plenty of sleep."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from J. T. Nettleship to My dear Mr. Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1879 Mar 25, 233 Stanhope St. N.W.; Begins: "It will give me great pleasure if you and Mrs Rossetti are able to come and see what I am sending to the Academy this year. []"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Postcard from F Madox Brown [Ford Madox Brown] to William Michael Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1886 Mar 4 [Postmark], 72 Elsam Road; Begins: "I shall telegraph to Watts that I need him at dinner tomorrow"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from N. Maccoll to Dear Rossetti [William Michael Rossetti]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1887 June 9, Athenaeum Office, 22 Took's Court, Cursitor Street, Chancery Lane, E.C.; Subject: concerning articles for publication in the Athenaeum.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Postcard from F. J. F. [Frederick James Furnivall] to William Michael Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1891 Mar 9; Begins: "Paris is a recognized English ward [?] "

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from H. C. Marillier to Dear Rossetti [William Michael Rossetti]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [before 1899?], Kelmscott House, Upper Mall, Hammersmith; Begins: "Can you tell me from memory whom the initials 'G. G. H.' would represent?"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Mackenzie Bell to William Michael Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1897 Aug 11, 33, Carlton Road, Putney, S. W.; Subject: concerning a facsimile of a manuscript page of one of Christina Rossetti's devotional works.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from M. H. Spielmann to William Michael Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1899 Nov 27, Magazine of Art, La Belle Sauvage, Ludgate Hill, London, E.C.; Begins: "I am much obliged to you for your article, so promptly sent"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fragment: Writing sample, "For Mr. Jones"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Text Fragment: "For Mr Jones" with note in another hand that "This is as written by Mr. Tennyson, Dec: 18. 1865"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Envelope fragment addressed to Wm M Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: With partial Camden postmark visible, with pencil note on verso reading "Walt Whitman."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Envelope addressed to William Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: With Guilford postmark visible and pencil notation "G. F. Watts, R. A."

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wrapper addressed to W. M. Rossetti and signed by F. G. Stephens
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Wrapper only.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fragment containing autograph
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Autograph only.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fragment containing autograph
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fragment containing closing salutation and autograph

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fragment containing autograph
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fragment containing closing salutation and autograph

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to William Michael Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1858 Jan 19 in pencil]; Subject: My 3 .drawings in the American exhibition not returned in December. I need them at once: one is sold. Marked "Absolon the water-colour Painter." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to William Michael Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1857 Aug 25 in pencil]; Begins: "I return the paper [?] filled up [...] " Green[?] had the two pictures; no need to send the large one. I'm exhausted. Venice was too hot to work in; but much taken with the Swiss mountains. [Top half only of sheet.] Marked "Anthony the Landscape-painter" Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to William Michael Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1858 July 17, Hardwick Inn, Derby'e [Derbyshire]; Summary: Your letter sent to me here; thanks for 36 pounds for the "Forest scene" sold at Philadelphia; you had not told me of the other at Boston. Will write to Ruxton for Instructions. Marked "Bennett, Water-colour Landscapist." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Rossetti" [William Michael Rossetti]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1858 Feb 17, 34A Gloucester Road, N.W; Summary: I am willing to sell "The Glacier" and the "Bank whereon" (though I meant to send the latter to the British Artists Exhibition). All I have to send is a Swiss water colour which you may not care to send. Discuss it with you this evening. Marked "Brett, the Landscape-painter." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to William Michael Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1858 Mar 3, 10 Hyde Park Gate ; Summary: Glad that one of my works to be bought in Philadelphia. Shall send other pictures: The flight of fayre Helen, and Paul and Silas. Ruxton's suggestion that the pictures remain until the New York season. Sold my Rutland house. Marked "Edward Cabould, water-colour Painter." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Sir"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1857 [?] Dec 5 [?], Red Hill, Reigate; Summary: Have sent Mr Green ten [?] drawings for the American Exhibition. Herewith a corrected list of my contributions: "List for New York Exh'n" [5 titles, priced]. Marked "Charles Davidson, Water-colour Landscapist." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. M. Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1858 Mar 4 penciled in], 56 Camden Square NW.; Summary: After our Gallery opens in May I'll finish a picture for America. Glad that the panic subsiding so that the Exhibition probably will be attractive. To be supported by British Artists good chance of a sale necessary. Marked "Geo. Fripp, water-colour Landscapist." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Wm Rossetti"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1858 Feb 3, 3 Abercorn Place NW; Summary: Your letters of 27 Jan and 1 Feb assure me that my Pictures will return to me soon. "The result of this attempt to establish British Art in the New World has been anything but satisfactory." Marked "J.D. Harding, the late Landscape painter." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter W. M. Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1857 Dec [?] 17, 2 Tor Villas, Campden Hill; Summary: I may leave my pictures in New York. Are the additional Exhibitions being carried out in the States? Marked "Horsley, R.A -- painter." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. M. Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1858 Mar 11, Embossed: "Athenaeum Liverpool"; Summary: Have forwarded "the Greenhouse" picture by Miss Hunt; price. Next year perhaps a better one than the one now lent. Good notion to have an exhibition-room not confined to a particular date: I would join such a society. Marked "Alfred Hunt, Landscape-painter." Note: "Miss Hunt" may be his sister Maria (see DNB). Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. M. Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1857 Sep 5 [8th?] [??sburgh] Terrace, Regents Park; Summary: Mr Green has received my pictures, done expressly for the New York Exhibition (I had nothing unsold and did not like to borrow). Those Gambart sent are very small oils, those I sent are in water. Marked "George Lance, the late admired Still-life Painter." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Sir"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1857 in pencil] Aug 25 , Paris, 21 rue Pigalle; Summary: The Post Office failed to deliver your letter and Prospectus of the projected Exhibition of British pictures in America. I would like to contribute; would you write to me soon, as I start in a fortnight for Africa? Are you Dante Rosetti's [sic] brother? remember me to him. Marked "Leighton the Painter." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Leighton of Stretton, Frederic Leighton, Baron, 1830-1896 (aut)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. M. Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1858 Mar 6, 16 Doughty St. Mecklenburgh Square W.C . Summary: Sorry for the delay (my move); happy to contribute a picture to the Boston Exhibition before the 12th. A previous picture of Hamlet also possible if you need filler. Marked "Marks the Painter." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Sir"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1858 Nov 19, Old Government House, Guernsey; Summary: Only 2 pictures of my 3 have returned from the American exhibition. Marked "Naftel, Water-colour Landscapist." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. M. Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1858 Mar 18, 12 Porchester Terrace, Bayswater W; Summary: Sorry that I'll have no work available for the Exhibition in New York this year. Marked "J. M. Richardson, water-colour Landscapist." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. M. Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1858 Dec [Jany in pencil] 4, Norfolk House, Westbourne Grove, West St; Summary: When will my 2 drawings return from the American Exhibition? I answered the circular to say that I did not want them exhibited again. Marked "Rowbotham, Water- colour Landscapist." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti. Note: The father, Thomas Leeson Rowbotham, signed himself "Thomas Rowbotham" and died in 1853. The son, Thomas Charles Leeson Rowbotham (or Thomas Leeson Charles Rowbotham) signed himself "Thomas L. Rowbotham" or "T.L . Rowbotham" or "T.L. Rowbotham, jun." [cf DNB, Benezet, BM, LCNAF, pNUC]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. M. Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thursday [1857 Sep 10 in pencil] , 2 Fitzroy Sq.; Summary: Repeating the title "At early dawn the ..." and price of the picture for the American Exhibition. Marked "Sand, the portrait painter." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. M. Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Monday [1857 Aug 10 in pencil], 11 Upton Park Villas Slough; Summary: Sorry for your lack of success with Mrs Gibbons. Mrs Ward hopes Mr Gambart might lend her "May Queen", though the Lady's Exhibition just borrowed it. My "Sleep of Argyll" is being engraved by Lloyd the publisher, and I doubt it can be spared. Marked "E. M. Ward, R.A. Painter." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Sir"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: [1857 Aug 29 in pencil]; Summary: Although the picture of the little boy was sent by mistake, you may add it to the number: any name, 15 pounds. Marked "Warren. President of the Water-colour Institute." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to W. M. Rossetti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1858 Mar 2 , 7 Lidlington Place; Summary: Your letter failed to reach me in Wales, so I didn't contribute to your first [?] gathering of Pictures. My only available picture is going to Bristol. But if the Committee forms another Exhibition for N. York in the Autumn, I shall contribute. Marked "Brittan Willis -- Water-colour Painter of Cattle &c." Annotator probably W. M. Rossetti.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Note to William Doremus Paden [?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: London; Note accompanying gift of Olivia Rossetti Agresti correspondence. Sent to Professor W. D. Paden. [?]

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Card to "Dear old Friend" [Mr. Robertson Scott?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: New Year greeting card. Begins: "Your message of hope and encouragement for the coming year was very welcome. []"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Mr. Robertson Scott"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1935 March 25. Begins: "I enclose cheque for 30/, being my subscription to the Countryman for 1935 for myself" On Associazione fra le Societa Italiane per Azioni letterhead, Roma.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "My dear Mrs Robertson Scott"
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1935 July 31, 3 St. Edmund's Ter. London; Begins: "We got home very comfortably yesterday and on the way up talked of the delightful hours we had passed under your hospitable roof []"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Carbon Copy Letter to "Dear Sir" regarding Olivia Rossetti Agresti
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1945 June 6, 14 Three Kings Yard, Davies Street, London; Begins: "Before the war Mrs Agresti (daughter of William Rossetti), whose husband was an editor of 'Tribuna,' visited us here []." Carbon Copy.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear Sir" [J. W. Robertson Scott, Esq.]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1945 June 8, R. Rappresentanza Italiana, 14 Three Kings Yard, Davies Street, London; Begins: "With reference to your letter of 6th inst., addressed to H. E. Count Carandini []." Signature lists A. Vanzetti as private secretary to Count Carandini.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to "Dear old Friends" [Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Robertson Scott?]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1950 Feb 13, Via Ciro Menotti, 36, Rome; Begins: "Dear old Friends: / For such you will allow me to call you, I was so delighted to et your letter of 10th inst. And hope this will reach you before you start on your long voyage to wish you God-speed and all best hopes and wishes for Mrs. Scott's health [...]"

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter to Mr. and Mrs. Robertson Scott
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 1952 Dec 16, Via Ciro Menotti, 36, Rome; Begins: "I[t] game me a great pleasure to receive your card today and to see that you remember me. I was talking about you with my sister, Mrs. Angeli, who now lives in Rome (our old London home was blown up by a flying bomb at the end of World War II [...])."
